paragraphs.name: 2c66
paragraphs.text: There’s quite a few snowflakes on here getting triggered by the idea that people don’t mind political influence in their sports articles.
The people who lean left don’t feel the need to shout and scream until someone they disagree with shuts up, which is what you see on political articles on this site without fail.

ab3cf6304ef2.title: It isn't. Sorry to break it to you buy I couldn't give a fuck about your political beliefs or any…

paragraphs.name: 3ed2
paragraphs.text: It isn't. Sorry to break it to you buy I couldn't give a fuck about your political beliefs or any other sports writers political beliefs. That is one of the biggest issues with this site compared to Grantland. You're trying to force your sports audience in the same echo chamber of your political beliefs.

paragraphs.text: Ironically if you are dealing with the text book definition of liberal modern sports writers are completely the opposite. If one doesn’t toe the liberal(political definition) line they are shamed and attacked. Having concerns over little girls sharing a bathroom with men makes you a bigot.

407a10f53787.title: There used to be a time when people used sports as an escape from politics.

paragraphs.text: There used to be a time when people used sports as an escape from politics. Thanks to ESPN, that has all changed. The other big change is that since implementing this PC Bro code, ESPN is hemorrhaging 10,000 subscribers per day. It is now a full fledged social justice network, even their ombudsmen admitted such. The Ringer is following the same…

content.subtitle: Sportswriters writing about the politics of sports is both necessary and proper. And, their positions on these issues don’t line up with…

paragraphs.name: fb8b
paragraphs.text: I think this article confuses two things: the politics of sports and politics outside of sports. Issues like the NCAA not paying their players (and punishing them for getting paid) are the politics of sports. Issues like Donald Trump’s election or Travel Ban are politics outside of sports.

And, make no mistake about it, we are winning and gaining even more support as we do so. People like you who fancy yourselves as…

b6f3d481a0cf.title: Something else here matters: sportswriters are immersed in a very heterogeneous sports world of…

paragraphs.text: Something else here matters: sportswriters are immersed in a very heterogeneous sports world of race, gender, religion, & upbringing. When you cover these athletes every day and know their stories, it’s pretty hard to turn a blind eye politically.

paragraphs.name: 655e
paragraphs.text: Well done. This is one of the main reasons my interest in sports in general is waning. I dropped cable because it was expensive. When a less expensive option became available I realized TV was really a time suck and didn’t buy in. The only thing I really missed about cable was live sports, so I turned to sports writing — primarily on the internet.

paragraphs.name: f1ed
paragraphs.text: Unusually fantastic piece.

ef10decfd63d.title: I thought this was an entertaining article about the recent history of liberalism in sportswriting.

paragraphs.name: a9d1
paragraphs.text: I thought this was an entertaining article about the recent history of liberalism in sportswriting. Would be interested in more about the early years (20s — 50s) and the first wave liberalism (Ali and Brown era). And the era of conservatism being the rule on the sports page.

d6127cbcb418.title: This article is a pretty good explanation for why viewing is falling for ESPN and other similar…

paragraphs.name: daae
paragraphs.text: This article is a pretty good explanation for why viewing is falling for ESPN and other similar outlets. In recent years, the sports pages have been pretty much the only part of the NYT that I could stomach, and apparently that’s on the way out, too. Oh well, I’m sure that market demand will produce alternative venues that will write and talk about sports without the SJW bromides.

paragraphs.text: Any time you try to split politics into a single axis, you’re left with some hamfisted and messy attempts to fit everything into a broad category. Even a 2 axis plot will be ugly, but it works better. What this article sorely misses is that second axis — authoritarian vs freedom. An NCAA player should be free to negotiate contracts outside of the one…
